description: From circa 1305, Middle English podynge (“kind of sausage; meat-filled animal stomach”), puddynge, from Old French boudin (“blood sausage, black pudding”), from Latin botellus (“sausage, small intestine”). Doublet of boudin.

entries.meaning: Any of various dishes, sweet or savoury, prepared by boiling or steaming, or from batter.
examples: The dishes in this chapter represent a range of multiethnic savory custards and steamed puddings, including a few surprises like a chèvre popover pudding and a bread pudding with lettuce and cheese.

entries.meaning: A type of cake or dessert cooked usually by boiling or steaming.
examples: Steamed puddings, a favourite for winter, are both easy to make and delicious. Served with one of the sweet sauces (recipes 497 to 506) they make a filling and satisfying end to a meal.

entries.meaning: A type of dessert that has a texture similar to custard or mousse but using some kind of starch as the thickening agent.
(UK, Australia, New Zealand) Dessert; the dessert course of a meal.
examples: We have apple pie for pudding today.

entries.meaning: (originally) A sausage made primarily from blood.

examples: Eat your pudding, slave, and hold your tongue.

entries.meaning: (archaic, slang) A piece of good fortune.
